docs.lead_paragraph: Henry Harris had a new girlfriend, and it was beginning to get serious. So last summer, Mr. Harris, 24, a high school safety officer from Brooklyn, decided it was time to be tested for H.I.V. and other sexually transmitted diseases. ''If two people are going to get together in this day and age,'' he said, matter-of-factly, ''you really need to make sure everybody is clean.''

headline.main: Men's Reproductive Health Care Gets New Emphasis

docs.abstract: Article on, Young Men's Clinic, joint project of Columbia University's Mailman School of Public Health and New York Presbyterian Hospital, which offers free medical care, including physicals, to low income men and those lacking health insurance; director David Bell says center's main goal is sexual health needs of young men, who have high rates of sexually transmitted diseases; photo; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Just because a medication once sold only by prescription is now available over the counter does not mean that patients know how and when to use it properly. A good example involves the antifungal products now sold without prescriptions for the treatment of vaginitis -- not just any vaginitis, but the most common form, caused by the ubiquitous yeast of the genus Candida. The fine print on the back of the box of the leading product, Monistat 3, warns, ''Do not use if you have never had a vaginal yeast infection diagnosed by a doctor.'' That is meant to ensure that a woman who walks into a drugstore with a self-diagnosis will know that she indeed has a vaginal yeast infection and not something else -- something potentially more serious -- for which this product is inappropriate.

headline.main: Yeast Infection: The Pitfalls of Self-Diagnosis

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on findings of study directed by Dr Daron G Ferris of Medical College of Georgia, published in March issue of Obstetrics and Gynecology, showing that only one third of women buying over-the-counter vaginal antifungal product Monistat 3 accurately self-diagnosed their conditions; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A decision by Britain's largest supermarket chain to hand out free morning-after pills to teenagers has sharpened a national debate over efforts to curb the country's rate of youth pregnancies, the highest in Western Europe. Britain recorded 95,000 teenage pregnancies in 2000, and the government has pledged to halve that number by 2010. As part of that effort, the emergency contraception known as the morning-after pill was allowed to be sold over the counter a year ago.

headline.main: British Store Gives Women Emergency Pill, Igniting Debate

docs.lead_paragraph: IT has been four years since Sylvia Ann Hewlett set out to write a book celebrating the achievements of what she calls ''the breakthrough generation'' -- women facing 50 at the millennium who ''broke through the barriers and became powerful figures in fields previously dominated by men.'' She started on her project by interviewing high-achieving, high-earning women like Jessye Norman, Diane Sawyer and Donna Shalala. Several months into her work, however, her project ceased to feel like a celebration. All the women she had interviewed had one unexpected thing in common: childlessness. So Ms. Hewlett, founder of the National Parenting Association and author of ''The War Against Parents'' (Houghton Mifflin, 1998) spent the next four years interviewing 100 successful women and conducting a statistical study of hundreds more. The result was ''Creating A Life: Professional Women and the Quest for Children,'' to be released by Talk Miramax Books next month.

headline.main: For Women, the Price of Success

docs.abstract: Lisa Belkin column on childlessness among high-achieving, high-earning women, subject of forthcoming book by Sylvia Ann Hewlett, Creating a Life: Professional Women and the Quest for Children; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When the Bronx Citizens Committee Alcohol Crisis Center, a rat-infested, asbestos-ridden detox center, was badly in need of renovation, Assemblywoman Gloria Davis took a particularly strong interest in the project, according to one of the main people involved in the center's overhaul. She sent a representative to nearly every design and construction meeting, the official said, and when it came time to make a list of the contractors that would be invited to bid, her representative added the name of the company that eventually won the contract.

headline.main: Bribery Case Ties Bronx Lawmaker to $1 Million Contract

docs.abstract: Bronx Assemblywoman Gloria Davis is under investigation by Manhattan district attorney's office involving how contract to renovate Bronx Citizens Committee Alcohol Crisis Center, worth $1 bmillion, was given to JPM Associates and whether kickbacks were paid; also under investigation is Carlos Jenkins, who was lawyer for detox center until he was elected to Bronx judgeship last year; Jenkins has given up his judgeship and his law license; state agencies involved in renovation of Bronx center, State Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services and State Dormitory Authority, have been questioned by investigators; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Led by Moses, the Jews fled en masse from Egypt around 1250 B.C., after centuries of bondage. So says the Bible's book of Exodus. But later books -- II Kings and Jeremiah -- report that 800 years later, during the fifth century B.C., Jews were once again living and worshiping there. The later biblical account was confirmed by the 1893 discovery of hundreds of papyrus scrolls from a settlement on Elephantine Island in the Nile. Eight were given to the Brooklyn Museum of Art in 1947 by Theodora Wilbour, daughter of Charles Edwin Wilbour, a pioneering American Egyptologist. Ms. Wilbour found them in a trunk after her father's death, but they were not opened and studied until 1953.

headline.main: Jews at Peace in Egypt, a Tale Told on Papyrus

docs.abstract: Grace Glueck reviews exhibition at Brooklyn Museum, Jewish Life in Ancient Egypt: A Family Archive From the Nile Valley, consisting of papyrus scrolls and art works; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Felicia Harris enrolled at St. Peter's College, the man she would come to know affectionately as Granelli sat her down for a heart to heart, one on one. ''You're an attractive young lady and guys are going to hit on you,'' he said, catching her off guard, elbowing his way right into her personal life. ''That's not what you're going to college for.'' These weren't exactly the freshman fundamentals she expected from the basketball coach. Four years later, Harris has already graduated and is working on her master's in accounting. She will be playing in what could be her last game when St. Peter's plays Cincinnati in the N.C.A.A. tournament tomorrow in Columbia, S.C. Now she can appreciate what the frank talk from the no-nonsense North Jersey guy was about.

headline.main: Sports of The Times; At St. Peter's, Coach Tells It Straight

docs.abstract: Harvey Araton Sports of The Times column discusses tough-talking attitude of Mike Granelli, long-time coach of women's basketball at St Peter's College in Jersey City (NJ) who has nurtured dozens of struggling teenagers and underdog team to impressive victories over years; photo (M)
